text: knewt wants apt-build to work for him
er, is apt-build in a package?
the terminal will be there, after X takes off and goes home
SHOULD YOU create a 2 GB partition for swap?
what was up with the 2gb question whallago?
i thought it was funny, watchin all the little windoze msg windows spawn via wine
didnt want to wait til they ate all the memory, so i killed wine
dude.....sure, but sudo reauthenicates when you open a  new gnome terminal
so the chances of that are mitigated
but if the user is ignorant of the command, does it matter?
thought you had to push with your foot, to go backwards in a microsoft porsche
What parts of the Ubuntu guide are bad?
i don't have a list of 'bad' commands, but advising new users to enable non-official (and newly-official) repos for constant use is not good
while backports have been 'officialized', they still have not 'synced' fully, imho
the 'guide is more written for advanced linux users (who know what the commands are/do)
correct, i see it more as a 'redhat/suse/gentoo > ubuntu/debian guide'
and some of plain out-n-out does not work
let me ask, how many New Users know if they have PPC, x86 or amd64 in their boxen?
thats why the popup exists.. .. .. to whop ubuntuguide advisors with
i would never modify configuration files *to get what I want* if I were a new user
new users are ignorant of that
new users are especially at risk from ubuntuguide
okay.....is the fud about backports true?
once backports has been more integrated into the ubuntu official process, there should be no stigma
but for now and in the past, using BP constantly definitely would break your system
i advise (if you are dying to get a certain program) to enable those repos, get what you want, and then comment them out
how long have you been hanging in here?
how many users have you seen have to reinstall becuase of constant unofficial repo usage?
seen? uh, well, i have not been idling
uni and multi are looked over and seen to play nice with ubuntu
/boot on a seperate partition keeps 'accidents' from happening

<jasoncohen> kbrooks, why do you recommend that people install from backports and then remove the backports entry? if they do that they won't get any updates which is far worse than just using backports whole
i dont advise removing the BP entry, just comment it out, because at the current time, prolonged use may cause system breakage in the future
as has been pointed out, bp is official now, and will become more stable as time goes by
it means I want your attention
see what i just told vladuz976 above
i did the configuration and chose nvidia
if you're having video trouble and want productivity over acceleration, read what i've been discussing with vladuz976 and choose VESA also
um, no. why should i choose vesa?
no. no screens found and nvidia api error
you and vladuz976 are doing the same thing, please read what i've been advising him
do you want to see a gui?
if you are using the 'nv' driver NOW, it isnt working too well
how many puters do you have in front of you?
would you rather see a gui so you can use firefox/xchat or whatever and attempt to find a solutin of why your NV makes blank screens?
wen i say nv, i dont mean nvidia
i don't know the diff tween them, but VESA will get you a gui
VESA will drive a dead dog
no, but i'll have to ask you to explain, please
delire hit it on the head
read what delire said to qosmos
yes i know, its for things YOU install
colony is the code for breezy development, i believe
i believe it is (ie colony2, colony3, etc)
if so, is the code in colony 'latest', as mojo claims it isnt?
i think cedega-cvs is nonfree, by definition
it can be done, in memory
i dont think it could be done
it can be done, you just lose your settings on reboot
should alien be recommendeeeeed to ANY ubuntu user?
tools are tools, they can be recommened with pros and cons and allow the user to make up their mind
there are some things only available in RPM (unfortunately)
you're right, but rpm is incompatible with debian/ubuntu
and that is what alien is for (if necessary)
*I* have used alien once before...to convert a xawtv rpm to a xawtv debian format
oh fuck. shall i leave for a while?
why not? work on the wiki or something
Velcan just mentioned another reason i like ubuntu
with ubuntu, more things work out-of-the-box then on other distros i've experienced
how long have you been on ubuntu?
well, between 0 and warty, there have been live cds
i dont forsee a problem when i build a amd64 box
fingering is common internet behavior, i hope you have an interesting .plan file

it's where you cant upgrade b/c you use non official repos and the pkgs are so different
if you use nonofficial repos, no thought is put into ubuntu upgrade compatibility

I like choice. Choice is magical. :)
